title.narrative: Grid-Connected Rooftop PV Systems in Seychelles

description.narrative: Seychelles - Grid-Connected Rooftop PhotoVoltaic Systems

title.narrative: Grid-Connected Rooftop Photovoltaic Systems in Seychelles
Terminal Evaluation for Grid Connected roof Top PV In Seychelles
Project Completion Report for PV Project

description.narrative: Grid-Connected Rooftop Photovoltaic Systems:
independent political entity
Increase the use of grid-connected photovoltaic (PV) systems as a sustainable means of generating electricity in selected main islands and smaller islands of the Seychelles
Amount of reduced CO2 emissions from the power sector (compared to the project baseline) by EOP, tonnes CO2eq

comment.narrative:
Target 80.4%: Achieved
It is estimated that emissions reduction of 977.2 tonnes CO2eq has been achieved as of 15 July 2015. According to the Seychelles Energy Commission, the amount of CO2 displaced by 1 unit (1 kWh) of electricity generated from PV is approximately 700 grams. The installed capacity for PV was 92% achieved in mid-July (and projected to be close to 100% achieved by end of July). The CO2 emissions reduction given as of mid-July is indicative of the weighted time period over which said capacity has been installed.

description.narrative: Cumulative installed capacity of grid-connected PV systems (kWp)

comment.narrative:
Target 92%: Achieved
Installed grid capacity from PV as of mid-July 2015 is 1,242.8 kWp.

description.narrative: Cumulative total electricity generation from installed grid-connected PV systems (kWh)

comment.narrative:
Target 82.2%: achieved
Total electricity generation from PV systems had reached 1,396,029.7 kWh by mid-July 2015. This is based on the installed capacity and average specific yield of the PV systems.
row added by mistake

description.narrative: Comprehensive and strengthened policy and legal frameworks adopted to promote RETs and enable grid-connected renewable energy production
No. of grid-connected RE production projects approved and facilitated by the IER by EOP

comment.narrative: At least 30

100% achieved and surpassed. There are currently 163 installations installed (July 2015).
The systems installed are mostly between 3-7 kWp, with most systems being installed in the domestic sector. As noted in the last reporting period, "block shaving" has been and continues to be the governing mechanism for determining system sizes in the domestic sector. The commercial sector is responsible for the larger (but fewer) installations. This is related to overall energy consumption, as block shaving is irrelevant to the commercial tariff.

description.narrative: No. of grid-connected RE production projects that benefitted from the enforcement of the strengthened legal frameworks by EOP

comment.narrative: At least 30

Target 100% achieved and surpassed.
As noted above, the number of systems, all of which are relevant to this indicator, stands at 163 as of mid-July.

description.narrative: Volume of funding mobilized or granted) from the incentives scheme by EOP, US$

comment.narrative:
Target 100% achieved.
A financial rebate scheme has been developed, with clear systems and processes. The scheme has involved the pooling of GEF funds and Government funds into a single account at the Development Bank of Seychelles (DBS). A GEF contribution of US$ 633,000 has been paid in and the Government has contributed SR 11.9 million (approximately US$ 915,000), for a total of US$ 1,548,000 to date.

description.narrative: Enhanced national capacity for the development, operation, and financing of RET systems
No. of entities in the country gainfully engaged in the various supply chain activities of the PV and RET markets by EOP.

comment.narrative: At least 10

Target 100% achieved.
A total of four PV supply and installation companies exist, and at least one other is in the process of being researched and registered. An additional 5 installers can be considered to be part of the national capacity. All PV systems installed in Seychelles have been installed by local expertise, which has been built as part of the project interventions.

description.narrative: No. of personnel of the MOF, local banks and FIs that are actively working on the formulation and implementation of incentive schemes and on the evaluation of the economic/financial viability of grid-connected PV system projects by end Year 1

comment.narrative: Target 100% achieved. More than 5 people are working to either assist with future iterations of the rebate scheme or FiT or SEEREP. One local bank has taken the initiative of developing a department specifically targeting RETs and EE, with several staff.

description.narrative: No. of local banks/FIs that are providing financial assistance to grid-connected PV system projects by EOP.

comment.narrative:
Target 100% achieved and surpassed
All five local banks are participating in the SEEREP, as noted in the last reporting period. This was achieved with the firm support and engagement of the Ministry of Finance, Trade and the Blue Economy (MFTBE), the Seychelles Energy Commission (SEC) and the project. The project is constantly monitoring and supporting the engagement of the local financial community with solar PV investments.

description.narrative: No. of joint ventures and/or licensing agreements between foreign PV manufacturers and local PV and RET companies facilitated by the business association by EOP

comment.narrative:
Target 100% achieved
Four companies - Solar World, Solar Watt, Stiens and Yingli - have official representatives in the Seychelles. Relationships between local companies and foreign suppliers are healthy, with all companies participating in supplier forums as well as training.

description.narrative: Increased electricity production from RET systems (e.g., PV systems) and interest among energy sector investors and operators.
Cumulative amount of reduced CO2 emissions compared to the project baseline from the demo projects by EOP, tonnes CO2eq

comment.narrative:
Target 80.4% achieved.
It is estimated that emissions reductions of 977.2 tonnes CO2eq has been achieved as of 15 July 2015. This is based on a grid emission factor of 700 grams of CO2 per kWh being offset by PV. The weighted time period has been considered in this calculation.

description.narrative: Cumulative total electricity generation from grid-connected PV systems by EOP, kWh

comment.narrative: Minimal
Target 82.2% achieved Cumulative generation is at 1,396,029.688 kWh as of 15th July 2015. This indicator is substantially the same as Indicator 3 (above).

description.narrative: No. of replication projects implemented that are based on or influenced by the success of the PV system demonstrations by EOP

comment.narrative:
Target 66% achieved Two projects are currently underway:
1. UNDP-GEF Resource Efficiency Project
2. Government Solar Homes Project In addition, the Government is in the process of designing a large project for potential GCF funding, focusing on a zero-carbon footprint of La Digue and Praslin islands. The approaches that will be adopted by this GCF project include widespread promotion and adoption of PV, building upon the initiatives of the current GEF project.

title.narrative: Management of Outer Island Protected Areas in Seychelles

description.narrative: Expansion and Strengthening of the Protected Area Subsystem of the Outer Islands of Seychelles and its Integration into the broader land and seascape

title.narrative: Project Document for Outer Island Project
Management of Outer Island Protected Areas in Seychelles

description.narrative: The project seeks to promote the conservation and sustainable use of terrestrial and marine biodiversity in the Seychelles’ Outer Islands.
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration
Promotion and up-scaling of climate-resilient, resource efficient technologies in a Tropical Island Context in Seychelles
Promotion and up-scaling of climate-resilient, resource efficient technologies in a Tropical Island Context
independent political entity
To significantly reduce the rate of electricity consumption and water usage in Seychelles among underserved communities in the residential sector

1. Amount of reduced CO2 emissions from the power sector (compared to the project baseline) - direct emissions reductions 2. Cumulative total electricity saved (MWh) 3. Cumulative total water saved (m3)

comment.narrative: 1. 139.590 tonnes CO2eq 2. 12,296 MWh per year (or 184,447 MWh for appliance lifetimes) 3. 446,250 m3 per year (or 6,693,750 m3 for device lifetime) - 20,060 tons of CO2eq over their lifetime.

Progress towards targets is not measurable at this time. Activities during the current reporting period, which did not actually start until late 2014, were focused on establishing an enabling environment for the project and in initiating, in parallel, activities that correspond to sub-components of the annual work plan. Attention was paid to the needs for defining policies and putting in place legislation needed, and developing baselines against which achievement of project targets (including carbon emissions reduction targets) could potentially be measured. It was realised, however, that specific attention is needed to develop a methodology that systematically quantifies the cumulative energy savings (and avoided CO2 emissions) of the measures and activities that are being developed - and thus provide a means of reporting against the objective-level targets. Attention will be paid to this during the next reporting period.

description.narrative: Comprehensive and strengthened policy and legal frameworks adopted to promote residential resource efficient appliances

4. Key baseline data collected and analysed (e.g. # of appliances and consumption patterns in households; consumer willingness or ability to pay; % of household spending that goes to electricity; etc.) 5. SEC Efficiency and Renewable Energy Unit operationalised with clear mandate / work plan and trained staff 6. Government-approved Energy Efficiency Strategy (EES) and Implementation Plan (EEIP) 7. Fiscal / tax incentives in place for imports and purchases of energy efficient equipment (except solar water heaters and energy saving lighting) 8. Restrictions (ban or limits) on imports of non-energy efficient appliances 9. System for measuring energy and water savings from EE residential appliances operational

comment.narrative: 4. No detailed information on residential or SME energy use 5. EE / RE unit proposed but not yet fully staffed or operationalised 6. None (only energy bill in place) 7. EE equipment (except solar water heaters and energy saving lighting) currently subject to Value Added Tax (VAT) 8. No restrictions in place for imports of non-EE appliances / no MEPS 9. No system in place for monitoring SEEREP by PUC

4. Baseline report completed by end of year 1 5. EE / RE unit fully operational by end of year 1 6. EES and EEIP approved by end of year 1 and published by end of year 2 7. Customs Act regulations amended to remove duties on EE equipment by middle of year 2 8. Government-approved minimum energy performance standards (MEPS) approved by end of year 1 9. Computer-based MRV system in place by end of year 1 at PUC

4. Target not met: baseline studies have been 10% achieved at the end of year 1. Two baseline studies have been initiated, one concerning water demand in the domestic sector and one concerning energy demand. The water demand study is expected to be completed at the end of September 2015; the energy baseline will be completed in May 2016. Baseline reports will thus not be ready until the end of year 2. 5. Target not met: set-up of the EE/RE unit 25% achieved at the end of year 1. The second draft plan for the set-up of the RE / EE Unit, prepared by the project ITE, was submitted to SEC in May 2015. The first staff of the unit (Principal Officer) joined SEC in June 2015 and will work with the project to fully establish the Unit by the end of 2015. 6. First target not met but on track to achieve second target. The recruitment process for a consultancy to draft a Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Strategy and Action Plan was not completed during year 1. The consultant was identified in May 2015 and will commence work shortly. The work is delayed somewhat by a review of the energy policy, by the project ITE, as there was a need for the elaboration of an amendment to the policy dedicated to EE and with defined targets for EE (both in terms of setting time limits for the initiation of national energy management programmes and for the application of specific energy targets when it is possible to define them - i.e., whenever baseline information is available). This policy amendment was submitted to SEC in April 2015. It will guide the implementation of the consultancy to develop the EE Strategy and Action Plan, which is expected to be completed by late 2015. 7. Target 10% met. Opportunities have been identified for revision of the VAT Act to widen the range of products that should receive VAT exemption. However, the reformulation of the VAT (and Customs) Act needs to be preceded by development, agreement and putting into place a technical validation procedure (to validate the eligibility of products). This technical validation procedure could be a complete Efficiency and Labeling Standards Programme, but could also be started up as a simpler process that will grow in complexity in a progressive manner, to allow for stakeholders to become progressively more familiar with the process and its objectives. 8. Target not met: preliminary work is underway but there is a serious risk that this target will also not be reached by the end of year 2 as the process is complicated. An integrated framework to develop the MEPS and the compliance facilitation processes and procedures was initiated in March-April 2015, but paused subsequent to a study visit of project staff and partners to Mauritius to interact with counterparts there that raised the possibility of simply adopting the framework applied there. This needs to be followed up, but meanwhile the ITE has developed an improved technical validation procedure that could replace the existing one (characterised as being limited and not very objective) and which could be the departing point to develop a complete Efficiency and Labeling Standards Programme. This alternative was submitted to the SEC in June 2015 and a decision on the way to proceed will be made shortly. 9. Target 10% met. A consultant was recruited to undertake a review of the SEEREP, recommend revisions, and provide an action plan to implement the recommendations. The initial review was completed and a report submitted in June 2015. The Ministry of Finance, which implements the scheme, did not yet express its views on the report. It is not known if SEEREP will continue or not. Note. To measure the impact of the project (energy and water savings) there is the need to develop a tool that is more encompassing than just monitoring the SEEREP. This had not been planned in year 1 and the activity to elaborate such a tool will start during year 2. The tool will be developed and maintained at the RE & EE Unit at SEC.

description.narrative:
Outcome 2.1 - Enhanced national awareness of the benefits of resource efficient appliances and verified behaviour change across targets groups regarding reduced energy and water use
Outcome 2.2 – Consumers of RSE appliances aware of goals and conditions of the financing schemes for RSE technologies and of purchase and financing options available through these programs

Outcome 2.1
10. Full implementation of the Seychelles Energy Education and Communication Strategy (SEECS) for residential sector 11. % of consumers and retailers aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and technologies via sampling and surveys 12. No. of sites in Seychelles where consumers, retailers and other stakeholders can learn about and see demonstrations of functioning energy efficient appliances 13. # of energy efficient household appliances and water savings devices for which labelling scheme (linked to MEPS) in place 14. Quantitative assessment and feasibility study of potential energy savings (kWh) of absorption cooling technologies in the Seychelles, and recommendations for strategies for increasing their uptake in the country Outcome 2.2
15. % of residential households and/or SMEs aware of goals, conditions and products offered by the financing schemes for RE technologies

comment.narrative:
Outcome 2.1
10. SEECS approved, but no large-scale actions implemented to date for residential sector 11. TBD by baseline study conducted in year 1 12. 0 sites with RSE appliances open to public 13. 0 labels exist in Seychelles linked to MEPS 14. Absorption cooling technologies very infrequently used in the country – exact # TBC by baseline study Outcome 2.2
15. TBD by baseline study conducted in year 1

Outcome 2.1
10. SEECS Action Plan, including component on residential water use reductions, approved and under implementation by end of year 1 11. At least 50% of target audience contacted (within the sample group) are aware of appliance energy efficiency standards and practices 12. 5 sites (2 households and 3 public facilities) established and open to public by end of year 3 of the project 13. Labels approved for at least 5 types of household appliances and 2 water saving devices by end of year 1 14. Assessment report on Absorption Cooling Technologies completed and disseminated to all relevant stakeholders by year 2 with targets specified for uptake potential Outcome 2.2
15. At least 80% of consumers/SMEs contacted (within the sample group) are aware of the different financing schemes or technology transfer platform offered for RSE technologies

Outcome 2.1 10. Target 10% met. The SEECS is being reviewed through a consultancy initiated in early June 2015. This is expected to be finalised in September 2015. The revised SEECS will be for the period 2015-2018, encompass aspects of water efficiency, and will provide an action plan for implementation. 11. Target not met. The baseline for this indicator is being defined as part of the contracted baseline studies, to be reported in the next PIR. A market survey was done in March 2015, encompassing 9 retail outlets, to determine retailer awareness. Consumer awareness is being assessed through a number of activities as follows: - The energy baseline study in the residential sector, which will encompass 1,000 households (3.5% of the households in Seychelles, stratified by income group) and will include explanation about RE, the benefits of adopting EE appliances and responsible use of energy.
- One trade fair was carried out in April 2015 in Mahé. The trade fair congregated about 15 suppliers of resource efficient technologies and was open to the public. During the trade fair, 100 visitors were assessed concerning their knowledge of EE appliances.
- The consultancy to revise SEEREP included a survey where 80 consumers on Praslin and La Digue were asked about their knowledge of EE appliances. All this information will be used to define the baseline for this indicator. 12. Target 10% achieved. A demo project has been initiated in La Digue school, with additional support from the SEC and the CCI. La Digue is the primary focus of Government to pilot processes leading to a carbon-neutral footprint. The project has been designed and the work will start soon. Another demo project is expected to be implemented at SIT (1 monitored solar water heater and 1 monitored rain water harvesting system) under a consultancy already planned and agreed with SIT (under Component 3.2). The other demonstration projects will be defined in the next reporting period. 13. Little progress towards the target as yet. The establishment of the E&L Standards Programme is still at an embryonic stage. 14. Little progress towards the target as yet. During the next reporting period a proposal will be made to engage an international consultant to provide the required input. Outcome 2.2
15. Target not yet met. Three surveys have been conducted so far to assess the level of knowledge of the public concerning the existence and objectives of SEEREP. The surveys have reached 100 persons on Mahé, 50 persons on Praslin and 30 persons on La Digue. The information resulting from these surveys and the information resulting from the baseline studies and revision of SEEREP will be used to establish the baseline for this indicator, which will be defined during the next reporting period.

description.narrative:
Outcome 3.1 – Platforms established for training of technicians in the installation, operation and maintenance of residential resource efficient technologies
Outcome 3.2 - Capacity of key stakeholders improved to monitor and enforce the Minimum Energy Performance Standards (MEPS) and new energy labelling scheme

Outcome 3.1
16. No. of private sector importers, dealers and retailers of household electrical appliances with access to market information (on product sourcing, pricing, quality, etc.) and maintenance of RSE technologies 17. Training platform established to train technicians on installation and maintenance of RSE technologies Outcome 3.2
18. No. of officers responsible for inspections of imported goods capacitated to evaluate compliance with relevant MEPS and related national labelling scheme

comment.narrative:
Outcome 3.1
16. Relevant private sector stakeholders have little to no knowledge of RSE appliances 17. No vocational training platform in place Outcome 3.2
18. 0 trained officers

Outcome 3.1: 16. At least 20 private sector partners have received training and support by end of project. 17. By end of project, Seychelles Institute of Technology (SIT) operating a certificate course for technicians in installation, operation and maintenance of resource efficient technologies (no. of technicians to be enrolled in course TBD during year 1) Outcome 3.2: 18. At least 10 trained officers by end of year 2 of the project

Outcome 3.1: 16. Preliminary work towards the target initiated. A market survey with well defined objectives was carried out in 9 shops of different retailers/importers based on Mahé. The action included some knowledge transfer and therefore contributed towards achievement of this outcome. A continuous and coherent training programme addressing importers, retailers and sales persons will be planned and initiated during the next reporting period. 17. Target 5% achieved. An exercise to assess the appropriateness of the existing course curricula and the ability of SIT to deliver the foreseen training has been completed. The TOR for the reformulation and development of the training courses has been completed and approved by SIT. After initiation of the consultancy it will be possible to determine the number of technicians to be enrolled in the course. Contact with the University of Seychelles was made in order to establish a training platform for short-term courses that would focus more on energy management, maintenance management and other technical topics (e.g. thermal simulation of buildings and planning of green buildings) that require specific knowledge but do not require long periods of time to be delivered. A first set of courses is proposed to be delivered in February 2016. Outcome 3.2: 18. No progress towards the target has been made this reporting period. The MEPS and the respective compliance evaluation procedures have not yet been established, and training cannot be undertaken until these are in place.

description.narrative:
Outcome 4.1 Regulations in place (linked to financing schemes) for safe disposal on non-EE residential appliances
Outcome 4.2 Underserved consumers accessing specially designated financial products for purchase of RSE appliances

Outcome 4.1: 19. Recycling of non-EE residential appliances mandated in policy and institutional responsibilities Outcome 4.2: 20. # of households receiving assistance from one of the identified financing/technology transfer platforms 21. No. of local banks that are providing loans to borrowers for purchase of resource efficient technologies 22. # of households to receive water-saving devices 23. Average electricity use per household (kwh/year) participating in SEEREP or other RSE financing platform

comment.narrative: Outcome 4.1: 19a. No specific policy exists for recycling of EE appliances; only a call for action under the new Solid Waste Management Policy (2014-2018) 19b. Voluntary code of practice for ODS use and disposal in the refrigeration/air-conditioning sector in place Outcome 4.2: 20. 0 21. 0 banks providing loans 22. 0 23. 4,395.7 kwh/year (average)

Outcome 4.1: 19a. Mandatory policy framework in place (to be implemented under the umbrella of the new Solid Waste Management Policy), which specifically includes guidelines and responsibilities for disposal of electronic waste and electrical equipment 19b. Policy and institutional mandate (MoU signed by LWMA) in place by end of year 1 Outcome 4.2: 20. By end of project, at least 8,500 households or SMEs have purchased or received one or more of the covered RSE technologies from at least one of the platforms mentioned. At least 8,500 households participating in SEEREP by end of project, disaggregated by socio-economic status 21. At least 3 banks by end of project 22. 8,500 households 23. 1,512.8 kwh/year (average) by end of project

Outcome 4.1: 19a. No progress towards the target has been made this reporting period. During the next few months a detailed TOR will be prepared for a consultant to develop the policy framework for the establishment and enactment of a facility to manage the Electrical and Electronic Equipment Residues. 19b. No progress towards the target. Preliminary discussion has taken place: the drafting of the MoU will be part of the consultancy mentioned under indicator 19a above. Outcome 4.2: 20. Target less than 1% met. The review of the SEEREP financing mechanism put into place pre-project by MoFBE submitted an initial report in June. The uptake of SEEREP is very low – fewer than 20 successful applications. However, it is realised that the scheme was implemented without having important structuring and flanking measures in place. The consultant concluded that there are opportunities for improving the publicity, operation and monitoring of SEEREP. In particular, the monitoring of the number of households receiving the support of SEEREP is not recorded in a computer database and thus figures may not be entirely accurate. The position of the MoFBE regarding the continuation (or revamp) of SEEREP is not yet known. The consultancy underway to review SEEREP will also put forward alternative financial mechanisms to be developed to complement SEEREP. The consultant also proposed a new reduction in the target of SEEREP – from 8,500 to 5,600 (noting that the target of 8,500 is the Government’s target, which has been transposed as a project target). This has not yet been discussed by the SEC and partners. 21. Target 100% met pre-project. 7 banks have signed the MoU and 4 banks have already approved at least one loan through SEEREP. 22. No progress towards the target. Water-saving devices are not currently within the scope of SEEREP. If the MoFBE decides to continue with SEEREP, the action plan to reformulate it will need to increase its overall scope to add these devices (especially rain water harvesting systems). 23. Target not measurable as yet. The energy baseline study will provide information concerning the feasibility of this target.
